title: Engraved type into bracelet – anything close?
content:
Hello I posted this before, suspect it is hand-engraved and not necessarily based on any one font, but does anyone have any ideas?

Thanks!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317100600im_/http:/typophile.com/files/bild_5335.JPG)

Font: 

 Roman 

Solved By: 

 [donshottype](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317100600/http:/typophile.com/user/205259 "View user profile.")

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [bild.JPG](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317100600/http:/typophile.com/files/bild_0.JPG) | 133.87 KB |
author: hungrymoon

comments.content:
Looks too consistent for hand engraving.  
Bracelets, rings etc are usually engraved with a milling machine that uses fonts in a special format.  
Some of these have the same names as regular fonts.  
Others do not.  
I believe this one is in the latter category and is usually sold as "Roman."  
Here is a link to a typical list of engraving fonts:  
 [http://www.jewelryimpressions.com/fonts.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317100600/http:/www.jewelryimpressions.com/fonts.html "http://www.jewelryimpressions.com/fonts.html")  
There are a few variations in "Roman" among engravers, but they usually are pretty close to your bracelet.  
Don

"Roman" is a works well for engraving because it usually uses hairline terminations rather than ball terminals. Plus it has wide curves -- note for example the open J.  
Don

Aha, found a clear specimen of "Roman" in use!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317100600im_/http:/typophile.com/files/RomanInUse_4035.JPG)
  
Don
